Anyway this is part of what I like abt social media, I can post away on my page & it’s v easy for ppl to ignore me if they’re annoyed.

& I do think I should worry abt ppl’s opinions. I often talk a lot in social situations as in don’t give enough space to other ppl & interrupt ppl. & I don’t think those are good things for me. I even annoy myself bc I have to hear me chatter in my head all the time.
Like sure you might say you shouldn’t worry abt those ppl’s opinions. But that’s not the same thing as telling me my perception is flawed re thinking ppl find me annoying.

So I keep seeing posts abt various ND folks worrying abt being annoying & how that’s not true
& idk abt anyone else but for me that worry doesn’t come out of nowhere. Enough ppl have told me to my face that I’m annoying over the yrs that I think it’s a valid thing to worry abt

So far it goes like this: Mast cells release serotonin. SSRIs suppress mast cell activity. I get OD rxn to small doses of SSRIs due to a serotonin transporter gene variant. Ketotifen also suppresses mast cell activity. Ketotifen label lists “hyperexcitability” as OD symptom. QED
The good part abt hypomania but slightly clearer head this afternoon is that I can now spend time searching journal articles to propose a coherent hypothesis explaining my rxn. Bc no obvious takers.

This is another reason why the artificial divide b/w “mental” & “physical” health & silo-ing of diagnosis & treatment is so damaging. Medicine really really needs a proper systems approach. But the few places that claim to do so often just repackage “conversion disorder” 6/
The standardized screening tools fr depression etc should have a calibration section abt other health issues bc as is they’re likely overestimating in some cases & underestimating in others 5/

Similar for depressive symptoms. Is it depression causing fatigue or is it a different issue? Is fatigue maybe causing depression due to not being able to do stuff we want? Theoretically docs need to screen for “physical” causes first but IME they don’t 4/

Like my hypomania almost never looks like the way it’s described in these guides bc while my mind may be going really fast my body can’t keep up. The “decreased need for sleep” thing is meaningless in my case w/o taking into acct my other health issues 3/

For example, diagnostic questionnaires for psych issues incl depression, anxiety & mania/hypomania always ask abt physical activity level but they don’t ask abt things like fatigue due to other illnesses impacting how you exp the psych symptoms 2/

You know we talk a lot on here abt how psych illnesses impact getting care for “physical” issues bc of everything getting called psychosomatic. But we also gotta talk abt how physical symptoms impact diagnosis & treatment of psych illnesses 1/

When I was v sick in a crisis a few yrs ago, my psychiatrist’s office told me to go to ER imm but don’t call 911 bc they’d send police & they’d try to handcuff me & that would not go over well. Awfulness of psych hospitals aside, many of us can’t safely access emergency help 9/

I’ve been pulled out of TSA line & subjected to extra screening for looking anxious bc no shoes on dirty floors bc of their “suspicious behaviour” detection program. Then when I cried while they patted me down bc OCD, they called the police on me 8/

For my citizenship application, I was asked questions if I was ever confined to a mental institution. I listed involuntary hospitalization & I had to reveal medical info during my citizenship interview so they could confirm I wasn’t “dangerous”  
This is only health q they ask 7/

I’ve experienced general disability discrimination at last job w/o them knowing the mental illness specifics but given things I’ve heard work supervisors say abt mentally ill ppl, the main reason I’m not public is to avoid employment discrimination 6/

Some recent ex of discrimination I’ve faced: docs seeing OCD on my chart & dismissing my symptoms as conversion disorder/health anxiety, paratransit denying appl bc apparently being able to ride train pre pandemic w panic attacks rest of day is evidence I don’t need help 5/

I’m v lucky to have grown up in a family that has supported psych care since I was 5 even in a country that has a few thousand psychiatrists in a population of a couple hundred million. I’m not ashamed of my illnesses. However I do experience discrimination abt them 4/
I feel like focusing on stigma & shame rather than discrimination leads to more “awareness” campaigns many of which are useless rather than trying to tear down systemic barriers re discrimination 3/

Right here on this app you see many of us are not ashamed of our mental illnesses or seeking help but many of us do use anon accounts to avoid discrimination whether in employment or school or personal lives. 2/

In 2022, I hope to see discussion abt mental illness shift from talking abt “stigma” when discrimination is what’s actually happening. Narrative of fuzzy stigma -> shame -> mentally ill ppl not being open or seeking help is only partially true. 1/

This tweet brought to you by me trying to fill a therapy intake form which gave one sentence space on what I need help w & M & F options for gender. Email complaining abt both has now been sent.

I’m not even trans but I instantly distrust any medical office only offering M or F for gender or even sex. Even apart from trans non-binary folks, intersex folks exist. It’s 2021. Medical offices need to catch up to ancient science.

On top of all that you have to deal w intersecting bureaucracies of medical offices, disability services orgs, insurance companies, pharmacies & the sheer incompetence at many places. & you have to be nice to them so they don’t make your life even more difficult

Unfortunately if you’re disabled medical gaslighting & associated trauma is an ongoing problem & patients aren’t misjudging the impact these can have on our lives. We still need help w dealing w it so we aren’t crying piles of goo every time we exp harm in medical settings.

I’m googling to see if I can find books to read on my own for now & the issue I’m coming across is that either therapy info abt trauma assumes the harmful situation is over so memories need to be dealt w or that the person is misjudging future threats or both.
Note I’m sure the book is helpful for the audience it’s intended for. But it’s clearly not intended for everyone. & there have to be multiple models to cover the range of human experiences.

I’m now running away from places only listing books like The Body Keeps the Score when talking abt medical trauma. Unironically need a therapy book like The Mind Keeps the Score when Body is subjected to Medical Gaslighting
My health issues aren’t a result of holding stress in my body. My emotional stress is a result of being denied necessary medical care & disability services over & over.

Emotionally traumatic experiences I’ve had in medical settings are ones where I’ve been told over & over that my health issues were a result of emotional stress. They’ve been wrong every single time & now I have objective proof.

Also like most of the therapists I’ve seen w profiles mentioning treating trauma & disabled patients seem to focus on “somatic” therapies. But those frameworks are precisely what cause me harm in medical settings.

Btw fun facts abt PPOs that reimburse out of network. They don’t cover % based on what’s charged. ref charge is from Medicare fee schedule for area. Medicare estimate for my area is $100 while actual is ~$200-300. So I only get reimbursed $60 after deductible for each appt.

Not sure where I was going w this. Just that the state of therapy options available is completely unsustainable for patients. & if you have issues like psychosis even many available therapists don’t want to treat you.

Also I’m completely out of medication options. I’ve had adverse reactions to every single one of my meds incl off label ones & experimental supplements my doc has tried w me. I’ve also had TMS. W/o meds I have frequent psychosis episodes. W meds I have neurological issues.

So my choices are to get therapy from someone like to retraumatize me or add up to $9K/yr in debt to my existing $40K of medical debt. My medical debt is a huge huge huge source of stress in my life. Going into debt for therapy seems totally counterproductive.

To add, lots of therapists do accept ins too. But any of the ones I’ve found who actually seem social justice / disability justice oriented in their work don’t take insurance or are not taking patients. Basically all 5 of them in the state I’ve found.

I completely understand why therapists don’t accept ins & at the same time this makes therapy completely inaccessible esp as low cost therapy is based on income. I’m v privileged income wise but at least 30% of my after tax pay goes to pay off med debt. I cannot afford more debt.

@crippledgoddex @bennessb Oh & treatment wise. It was mainly eat a low carb diet & small but more frequent meals. Eat something at least every couple hrs. But all meals also need some carbs. I was told at least 15 g carbs each meal to keep insulin dumping stable too.

@crippledgoddex @bennessb Also fun fact. The worst episode I had of reactive hypoglycemia (aka postprandial hypoglycemia), it felt like a panic attack. I did have my glucose meter w me so I did a quick measurement & it was v low compared to my fasting baseline.

@crippledgoddex @bennessb Mine only went “officially” hypoglycemic once. But it did fall to my fasting level w/in couple hrs. Endocrinologist said that still counted as everyone’s range for hypoglycemia can be different. I was clearly symptomatic.

@crippledgoddex @bennessb If it helps, this is what the endocrinologist I saw had me measure for blood sugar for 4 days:
Fasting, then before each meal. & keep a meal diary.
@crippledgoddex @bennessb I will say it can be hard to differentiate b/w POTS symptoms post meals vs hypoglycemia. I’d def recommend checking both BP/HR & blood sugar.

@EikoFried But if someone’s say mood or anxiety symptoms are entirely due to a bad social situation, that shouldn’t be pathologized in the first place.

@EikoFried Maybe another way to put it is that one’s body in general is impacted by bio & social factors. So “brain health” can be impacted by social factors like say “lung health” can be & in “mental” illness we’re talking abt that.
@EikoFried As a patient, in practice, biopsychosocial tends to be a red flag in clinician bios bc it usually translates to not actually getting help.

@EikoFried In practice, medicine can’t actually help w social factors either so they send patients to CBT which is the cheapest but possibly the worst therapy for social factors. Also discounted is that medicine is one of the biggest causes re social stressors.

@EikoFried This may also just be a theory vs practice thing.

In practice, even the known bio factors aren’t adequately screened for & even other specialties have a tendency to throw everything into a “conversion disorder” bucket w some nebulous “stress” causing everything.

@EikoFried & then that idea is being used to discourage the use of interventions like medications & brain stimulation even for serious illnesses & on the other hand, therapy practices geared towards ppl from marginalized groups don’t have exp working on these disorders.

@EikoFried There’s been an uptick, in my observation, w misrepresentation of epigenetics in media re generational trauma. I’ve seen a trend of labeling genetic predisposition to psych illnesses as being ultimately related to generational trauma, which is not what current research says.

@EikoFried Agreed. But my general point also is that that’s true of any other health problems even “physical” health problems. But in larger cultural circles esp on the left, there’s a def pushback against bio factors .

@EikoFried To borrow a theatre term “Yes &” would be a better framework. “Brain health & xyz”. 

But again the factors shared impact tons of other health issues also. But we still talk abt those in terms of those body sys. I’m not sure why psych stuff is singled out to discount bio factors.

@EikoFried But the tweets read as advocating to not use brain health when talking abt psych issues & that’s inaccurate. 

To me your tweet even if you don’t mean it that way is part of a pattern to de emphasize bio factors in detrimental ways.

@EikoFried I think the key part is “without a doubt”. Psychiatry lacks the tools to make a definitive pronouncement there. Until there are better tools to actually make that distinction & if what’s being advocated is to make that distinction that’s one thing.

@EikoFried I know you’re not trying to pill shame but I do see de-emphasizing of biological factors. As a patient I don’t even like using mental health bc it separates out the brain as being somehow separate from other body parts, which are also impacted by env factors.

@EikoFried The other issue is de-emphasizing bio factors unfortunately equals pill shaming. If the life stressors are the problem then we’re all supposed to get therapy (which can be harmful re env factors too) bc otherwise we’ve bought into big pharma propaganda abt bio issues

@EikoFried The issues I’ve experienced in this context are when talking abt the need for culturally competent therapists, the focus seems to entirely be on folks who can help address the env issues. It’s v v hard to find BIPOC HCPs who work w patients w ex. psychotic disorders

@EikoFried I think the post is well meant. But this only works IMO if the distinction can actually be made. I’ve been advocating for the distinction to be made actually. But w/o de-emphasizing the bio factors.

@EikoFried I’ll have to disagree as a patient. The swing to describing mental illness focused on env factors isn’t necessarily helpful to those of us who have v much bio issues. Until medicine comes up w tools to disambiguate bio factors vs env factors, bio part does need to be highlighted
